Title: Prophet Yunus (AS) and the Whale
Summary: Discover the story of Prophet Yunus (AS), who was swallowed by a giant whale! Learn how patience and dua can save us even in the darkest times.
Body:
The Prophet’s Mission
Prophet Yunus (AS) was sent to teach the people of Nineveh to worship Allah alone. But they refused to listen! Frustrated, Yunus (AS) left the city without Allah’s permission.


The Storm and the Whale
A storm sank the ship he boarded, and Yunus (AS) was swallowed by a giant whale! In the whale’s dark belly, he prayed: “La ilaha illa Anta, Subhanaka! (There is no god but You, Glory be to You!)” (Quran 21:87).


A Second Chance
Allah forgave Yunus (AS) and commanded the whale to spit him onto shore. When he returned to Nineveh, he was amazed—the people had finally accepted Islam!
Quranic Verse: “And had he not been of those who exalt Allah, he would have remained inside its belly until the Day they are resurrected. But We threw him onto the open shore while he was ill.” (Quran 37:143-144)
Vocabulary:
• Dua: A prayer to ask Allah for help.

  • Tawbah: Repentance (saying sorry to Allah and promising to improve).

  • Sabr: Patience and perseverance in Islam.
Reflective Questions:
• Why is it important to never give up on Allah’s mercy?

  • What can you do when you feel frustrated or impatient?

Title: Prophet Sulayman (AS) and the Ants
Summary: Learn how Prophet Sulayman (AS) spoke to animals, ruled with justice, and taught us to care for even the tiniest creatures!
Body:
The Kingdom of Wisdom
Allah blessed Sulayman (AS) with a mighty kingdom. He ruled over humans, jinn, and animals, and even commanded the wind! His wisdom and fairness made him beloved by all.


The Ants’ Warning
One day, Sulayman (AS) marched with his army through a valley. An ant leader warned her colony: “Hide! Sulayman’s army will crush us!” Sulayman (AS), who understood animal speech, smiled and ordered his army to stop. He said, “Allah teaches us to respect all life, even the smallest ants!” (Quran 27:18-19).


Queen Bilqis’s Test
The hoopoe bird told Sulayman (AS) about Queen Bilqis, who worshipped the sun. Sulayman (AS) sent her a letter inviting her to Islam. She replied with riddles to test him, but Allah gave Sulayman (AS) the answers. Amazed, Bilqis visited his kingdom and accepted Islam, saying, “I submit to Allah, the Lord of the worlds!”
Quranic Verse: “Until, when they came upon the valley of the ants, an ant said, ‘O ants, enter your dwellings that you not be crushed by Solomon and his soldiers while they perceive not.’ So [Solomon] smiled, amused at her speech, and said, ‘My Lord, enable me to be grateful for Your favor...’” (Quran 27:18-19)
Vocabulary:
• Hoopoe: A bird that served as Sulayman’s messenger.

  • Jinn: Creatures made of fire who obeyed Sulayman (AS).

  • Saba: The kingdom of Sheba, ruled by Queen Bilqis.
Reflective Questions:
• Why did Sulayman (AS) stop his army for the ants?

  • How can you show kindness to animals or insects?
Suggested Embeds & Activities:

Title: Prophet Musa (AS) and the Red Sea
Summary: Discover how Prophet Musa (AS) trusted Allah to escape Pharaoh’s army and cross the Red Sea—a miracle that teaches us courage and faith!
Body:
The Baby in the Basket
Musa’s (AS) mother hid him in a basket on the Nile River to save him from Pharaoh’s soldiers. Allah guided the basket to Pharaoh’s palace, where Musa (AS) grew up under Allah’s protection.


The Escape
Years later, Musa (AS) confronted Pharaoh, demanding he free the enslaved Israelites. When Pharaoh refused, Allah sent plagues. Musa (AS) led his people out of Egypt, but Pharaoh’s army chased them to the Red Sea!


The Splitting Sea
Allah commanded Musa (AS) to strike the sea with his staff. The sea split into two walls, letting Musa (AS) and his people cross safely. When Pharaoh’s army followed, the sea closed, drowning them all.
Quranic Verse: “And We inspired to Moses, ‘Strike with your staff the sea,’ and it parted, and each portion was like a great towering mountain. And We saved Moses and those with him, all together. Then We drowned the others.” (Quran 26:63-66)
Vocabulary:
• Pharaoh: A cruel king who ruled Egypt.

  • Torah: The holy book revealed to Musa (AS).

  • Miracle: An amazing act only Allah can do.
Reflective Questions:
• Why did Allah choose Musa (AS) to confront Pharaoh?

  • How can you trust Allah when something seems impossible?
Suggested Embeds & Activities:
YouTube Short Video: “Musa’s Journey” (animated 3-minute story with Quranic verses).

“Plagues Puzzle” Educaplay: Match Allah’s signs (e.g., frogs, locusts) to their lessons.

Optional Printable
“Courage Certificate”: Kids write/draw one brave act they’ll do this week.

Title: Angels in Islam: Guardians and Helpers
Summary: Angels are Allah’s special creations made from light! They never disobey Him and work day and night to protect us, deliver messages, and record our deeds. Let’s learn about these amazing helpers!
Body:
Creatures of Light
Allah created angels from light. They don’t eat, sleep, or get tired! They worship Allah constantly, saying, “SubhanAllah! (Glory to Allah!)” Some have wings—two, three, or even hundreds! (Quran 35:1).


The Angels Who Protect Us
Two angels sit on your shoulders every day:

  • Raqeeb writes your good deeds.

  • Ateed writes your mistakes.
    But Allah is Merciful—He forgives us when we say sorry!


Angel Jibreel’s Special Mission
Angel Jibreel (AS) brought the Quran to Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) in Cave Hira. He also helped other prophets, like teaching Adam (AS) how to grow crops and strengthening Isa (AS) as a baby.


Angels We Can’t See

  • Munkar and Nakir ask questions in the grave.

  • Izraeel gently takes souls when it’s time.

  • Ridhwan guards Jannah (Paradise), welcoming believers with “Salamun Alaikum!”
Quranic Verse: “[The angels say], ‘There is none among us except that he has a known position. And indeed, we are those who line up [for worship].’” (Quran 37:164-166)
Vocabulary:
• Mala’ikah: Angels in Arabic.

  • Rizq: Sustenance provided by Allah.

    • Rahmah: Mercy.
Reflective Questions:
1. How does knowing angels record deeds help you make good choices?

    1. Why do you think Allah gave us invisible helpers like angels?
Suggested Embeds & Activities:

“Angels Around Us” (2-minute animation showing angels’ roles, with Quran 13:11: “For each person, there are angels in succession, before and behind them...”).

Title: Prophet Ibrahim (AS): The Friend of Allah
Summary: Meet Prophet Ibrahim (AS), who stood up for Allah even when everyone else worshipped idols! Learn how his trust in Allah taught us bravery and faith.
Body:
The Boy Who Questioned Idols
Young Ibrahim (AS) lived in a kingdom where everyone worshipped statues. He asked his father, “How can you worship what you carve with your own hands?” When no one listened, he prayed to Allah for guidance.


The Fire of Faith
Ibrahim (AS) smashed the idols in the temple! The angry king threw him into a blazing fire, but Allah commanded the flames to be cool and safe. Ibrahim (AS) walked out unharmed, saying, “Allah is enough for me!”


Building the Kaaba
Years later, Allah tested Ibrahim (AS) again: “Leave your wife Hajar and baby Ismail in the desert.” When they ran out of water, Allah sent the Zamzam well! Ibrahim (AS) and Ismail (AS) later built the Kaaba, the first house of worship for Allah.
Quranic Verse: “And when he reached with him [the age of] exertion, he said, ‘O my son, indeed I have seen in a dream that I [must] sacrifice you. See what you think.’... And when they had both submitted and he laid him upon his forehead, We called to him, ‘O Abraham, you have fulfilled the vision.’ Indeed, We thus reward the doers of good.” (Quran 37:102-105)
Vocabulary:
• Tawheed: Belief in the oneness of Allah.

  • Idols: False gods made of stone or wood.

  • Zamzam: The blessed well in Mecca sent by Allah for Ismail (AS) and Hajar (RA).
Reflective Questions:
• Why did Ibrahim (AS) break the idols even though it was dangerous?

  • How can you stand up for what’s right, like Ibrahim (AS)?
Suggested Embeds & Activities:

“Ibrahim’s Leap of Faith” (3-minute animation covering the fire, Zamzam, and Kaaba).

Embed Code: Use Wix’s YouTube widget (lazy-loaded).

Drag-and-drop bricks to construct a digital Kaaba while learning fun facts.

Title: Prophet Nuh (AS) and the Ark
Summary: Learn how Prophet Nuh (AS) built a giant ark to save believers and animals from a great flood—a story of patience and trust in Allah!
Body:
The Call to Worship
Nuh (AS) preached for 950 years, asking his people to worship Allah alone. They laughed and threw stones at him, but he never gave up!


Building the Ark
Allah commanded Nuh (AS) to build a massive ark. People mocked him, asking, “Why build a boat in the desert?” But Nuh (AS) trusted Allah’s plan.


The Great Flood
Rain poured for 40 days, flooding the land. Nuh (AS), his followers, and animal pairs boarded the ark. When the flood ended, Allah made the ark rest on Mount Judi.
Quranic Verse: “So We inspired him, ‘Construct the ship under Our observation and Our inspiration...’ Until when Our command came and the oven overflowed, We said, ‘Load upon it of each [creature] two mates and your family...’” (Quran 11:40)
Vocabulary:
• Ark: A large boat built to survive the flood.

  • Patience: Staying calm during hardship.

  • Covenant: A promise between Allah and His servants.
Reflective Questions:
• Why did Nuh (AS) keep preaching even when people mocked him?

  • What can you do to stay patient during tough times?
Suggested Embeds & Activities:
YouTube Short Video: “Nuh’s Ark Adventure” (3-minute animation with sound effects).

“Flood Timeline” Educaplay: Sequence events (building the ark, rain, Mount Judi).

Title: Abdul-Rahman ibn Awf (RA): The Honest Merchant
Summary: Learn about Abdul-Rahman ibn Awf (RA), a companion of the Prophet (ﷺ) who showed us how to be honest in business and generous with wealth!
Body:
The Promise
Abdul-Rahman ibn Awf (RA) was a wealthy merchant in Mecca. When he became Muslim, he promised the Prophet (ﷺ) to always trade fairly. Even when others cheated, he sold goods at fair prices and said, “Allah sees every transaction!”


The Test
Once, he sold a caravan of dates but later found a hidden flaw in the goods. He ran to the buyer and said, “Take back your money—these dates are spoiled!” The man replied, “But you didn’t know!” Abdul-Rahman (RA) said, “Honesty is more valuable than gold.”


Legacy
He gave mountains of wealth as sadaqah. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, “Abdul-Rahman is successful in this life and the next!”
Quranic Verse: “O you who believe, do not consume one another’s wealth unjustly, but only in lawful business by mutual consent.” (Quran 4:29)
Vocabulary:
• Sadaqah: Voluntary charity in Islam.

  • Trustworthy: Being reliable and honest.

  • Caravan: A group traveling together for safety.
Reflective Questions:
• Why is honesty important even when no one is watching?

  • How can you practice fairness at school or home?
Suggested Embeds & Activities:
“Honesty Quiz” (Educaplay):

Scenario-based questions (e.g., “You find $10 on the playground. What do you do?”).

Embedded Animated Video:

“The Honest Merchant” (2-minute cartoon about Abdul-Rahman’s story).

“Honesty Tracker”: A simple chart where kids tally daily acts of honesty (e.g., admitting a mistake).

Title: Prophet Yusuf (AS): The Dreamer
Summary: Follow the journey of Prophet Yusuf (AS), whose beautiful dreams, betrayal by brothers, and unshakable patience teach us to trust Allah’s plan!
Body:
The Beloved Son
Yusuf (AS) was his father Yaqub’s favorite son. His brothers grew jealous and threw him into a well! But Allah saved him, and travelers rescued him.


From Prison to Palace
Sold as a slave, Yusuf (AS) was falsely accused and sent to prison. There, he interpreted dreams for inmates, saying, “Allah teaches me the meaning of dreams!” (Quran 12:36).


Reunion and Forgiveness
Years later, Yusuf (AS) became a wise ruler in Egypt. When his starving brothers came for food, he forgave them, saying, “No blame will be on you today. May Allah forgive you!” (Quran 12:92).
Quranic Verse: “They said, ‘O our father, indeed we went racing each other and left Joseph with our possessions, and a wolf ate him. But you would not believe us, even if we were truthful.’... And he turned away from them and said, ‘Oh, my sorrow over Joseph,’ and his eyes became white from grief, for he was [of] suppressed anger.” (Quran 12:18)
Vocabulary:
• Sabr: Patience during hardship.

  • Khimah: A special coat (given to Yusuf by his father Yaqub).

  • Tawakkul: Trusting Allah’s plan.
Reflective Questions:
• Why did Yusuf (AS) forgive his brothers after they hurt him?

  • How can you practice sabr when something unfair happens?
Suggested Embeds & Activities:

“Yusuf’s Journey” (animated retelling of his trials and triumphs).

“Prison Puzzle” Educaplay Game:

Solve riddles to “escape” prison by finding Quranic clues.

“Sabr Star Chart”: Kids earn stars for acts of patience (e.g., waiting their turn).

Title: The People of the Cave (Ashab al-Kahf)
Summary: Discover the amazing story of the youths who slept in a cave for centuries, protected by Allah’s mercy! Learn how trusting Allah can turn even the hardest tests into miracles.
Body:
The Brave Youths
Long ago, in a kingdom ruled by a tyrant king, a group of young men refused to worship idols. They believed only in Allah and faced terrible persecution. One night, they fled to a cave, praying, “Our Lord, grant us mercy and guide us!” (Quran 18:10).


The Miracle of Sleep
Allah put them into a deep sleep for 309 years! Their bodies never aged, and their loyal dog guarded the cave entrance. The sun’s light shifted to protect them from heat and cold (Quran 18:17).


Waking Up
When they awoke, they thought they’d slept a day or part of a day. One youth went to buy food with old coins, startling the townspeople. The king had changed, and the kingdom now worshipped Allah!


Legacy of Faith
The people marveled at Allah’s power. The youths’ story reminds us that Allah’s protection is greater than any fear, and He rewards those who stand firm in their faith.
Quranic Verse: “[The youths said], ‘Our Lord, grant us mercy from Yourself and prepare for us from our affair right guidance.’ So We cast [a cover of sleep] over their ears within the cave for a number of years.” (Quran 18:10-11)
Vocabulary:
• Tawheed: Belief in Allah’s oneness.

  • Persecution: Hurting others for their beliefs.

    • Divine Decree (Qadr): Allah’s perfect plan for everything.
Reflective Questions:
1. Why did Allah protect the youths even while they slept?

    1. How can you stay strong in your beliefs when others disagree?
Suggested Embeds & Activities:
YouTube Short Video: “The Sleepers of the Cave” (3-minute animated retelling with Surah Al-Kahf verses).

“Sunlight Shift” Interactive Diagram: Move a slider to see how sunlight avoided the sleepers (CSS/JavaScript-based).

Educaplay Quiz: “What Would You Do?” Scenarios about standing up for faith.

Optional Printable
“Cave of Faith” Journal: Kids write/draw a time they felt Allah’s protection.

Title: Maryam (AS): The Blessed Mother
Summary: Discover the story of Maryam (AS), a woman chosen by Allah for her piety and strength. Learn how her faith helped her overcome impossible challenges!
Body:
A Devoted Servant
Maryam (AS) grew up in the temple, praying day and night. Angels visited her and said, “Allah has chosen you above all women!” (Quran 3:42). She spent her time worshipping Allah and helping others.


The Miracle of Provisions
Whenever Maryam (AS) prayed, Allah sent her fresh fruits out of season! Her guardian, Prophet Zakariyah (AS), was amazed. She said, “Allah provides for whoever trusts Him.”


The Birth of Isa (AS)
One day, Angel Jibreel (AS) appeared and said, “Allah gives you glad tidings of a son named Isa!” Though scared, Maryam (AS) relied on Allah. When people accused her, baby Isa (AS) spoke from her arms: “I am a servant of Allah!” (Quran 19:30).
Quranic Verse: “And mention in the Book [the story of] Mary, when she withdrew from her family to a place toward the east. And she took, in seclusion from them, a screen. Then We sent to her Our Angel, and he represented himself to her as a well-proportioned man.” (Quran 19:16-17)
Vocabulary:
• Hijab: Modesty in actions and dress.

  • Rizq: Sustenance provided by Allah.

  • Miraculous: An event that only Allah can make happen.
Reflective Questions:
• How did Maryam (AS) show trust in Allah when she was afraid?

  • What can you do to be kind and patient like Maryam (AS)?
Suggested Embeds & Activities:

“Maryam’s Miracle” (3-minute animation with scenes from her life).

Title: Umar ibn Al-Khattab (RA): The Just Leader
Summary: Meet Umar ibn Al-Khattab (RA), the second Khalifa of Islam, who taught the world what true justice means—even when it was hard!
Body:
From Foe to Friend
Umar (RA) was once a fierce enemy of Islam. He hated Muslims and even planned to harm the Prophet (ﷺ)! But one day, he heard his sister reciting the Quran. The words of Surah Taha softened his heart, and he ran to the Prophet (ﷺ) and declared, “I accept Islam!”


The Khalifa Who Walked at Night
As Khalifa, Umar (RA) wore patched clothes and secretly walked the streets at night to ensure no one was hungry or mistreated. Once, he carried a sack of flour on his back to feed a poor widow and her children.


Justice for All
A Jewish man once accused Umar’s son of drinking alcohol. Umar (RA) punished his own son publicly, saying, “The law of Allah applies to everyone!”
Quranic Verse: “Umar said, ‘By Allah, if a female sheep dies under my care, I fear Allah will question me about it on the Day of Resurrection.’” (Al-Bidayah wan-Nihayah 7/161 | Ibn Kathir)
Vocabulary:
• Khalifa: A leader of the Muslim community (Ummah) after the Prophet (ﷺ).

  • Ummah: The global community of Muslims.

  • Hijri: The Islamic calendar starting from the Prophet’s migration (Hijrah).
Reflective Questions:
• Why did Umar (RA) punish his son even though he was the Khalifa’s child?

  • What can you do to be fair at school or home?
Suggested Embeds & Activities:
“Justice or Injustice?” Educaplay Game:

Sort scenarios into “Just” or “Unjust” (e.g., “Sharing toys” vs. “Cheating in a game”).

Title: The Army of Elephants (Surah Al-Fil)
Summary: Discover how Allah protected the Kaaba from a powerful army with tiny birds! A story of faith and divine power from Surah Al-Fil.
Body:
The Arrogant King
Abraha, the ruler of Yemen, grew jealous of the Kaaba. Pilgrims from all over Arabia visited Mecca to worship Allah, but Abraha wanted them to come to his grand temple instead. He carved statues of elephants from stone and shouted, “My temple is greater than the Kaaba!”


The March to Mecca
Abraha gathered a massive army, including a giant elephant named Mahmud. As they marched toward Mecca, they destroyed villages and terrified the people. The Quraish tribe prayed, “O Allah, protect Your House!”


The Miracle of the Birds
When Abraha reached Mecca, Allah sent flocks of Ababil birds from the sky. Each bird carried a tiny stone in its beak and claws. They dropped the stones on Abraha’s army, piercing their armor and turning them into “crushed straw” (Quran 105:5). The elephant Mahmud refused to move, and Abraha fled in shame, his body covered in sores!


The Kaaba Stands Strong
The Kaaba remained unharmed, and the people of Mecca celebrated Allah’s power. To this day, Muslims recite Surah Al-Fil to remember that no one can defeat Allah’s plan.
Quranic Verse: “Have you not considered how your Lord dealt with the companions of the elephant? Did He not make their plan into misguidance? And He sent against them birds in flocks, striking them with stones of hard clay.” (Quran 105:1-4)
Vocabulary:
• Abraha: The greedy king who attacked Mecca.

  • Kaaba: The sacred house of Allah in Mecca.

  • Flocks: Groups of birds.
Reflective Questions:
• Why did Allah use something small (birds) to defeat something big (elephants)?

  • How does this story make you feel about Allah’s power?
Suggested Embeds & Activities:
YouTube Short Video: “The Birds vs. Elephants” (animated 2-minute retelling).

“Stone Strike” Educaplay: Click birds to drop stones on a map of Abraha’s army.

Optional Printable

Title: Khadijah (RA): The Mother of the Believers
Summary: Discover the story of Khadijah (RA), the first wife of Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ), whose kindness, wisdom, and generosity helped spread Islam to the world!
Body:
The Successful Merchant
Khadijah (RA) was a wealthy and respected merchant in Mecca. She hired honest workers to lead her caravans to faraway lands like Syria and Yemen. When she heard about Muhammad’s (ﷺ) trustworthiness, she asked him to manage her trade. Impressed by his honesty, she later proposed marriage to him!


The First Believer
When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) received the first revelation in Cave Hira, he rushed home trembling. Khadijah (RA) wrapped him in a blanket and said, “Allah would never abandon you, for you are kind to family, honest in trade, and help the poor.” She was the first person to accept Islam, using her wealth to support the Prophet (ﷺ) and early Muslims.


Generosity in Hard Times
During the boycott of the Muslims in Mecca, Khadijah (RA) spent all her money to feed and protect the Muslim community. Even when she became poor, she said, “What I give for Allah’s sake will never be lost.”
Quranic Verse: “The Prophet (ﷺ) said, ‘She believed in me when others disbelieved. She held me truthful when others called me a liar. She spent her wealth on me when others deprived me.’” (Musnad Ahmad 24864 | Authenticated by Al-Albani)
Vocabulary:
• Tijaarah: Trade or business.

  • Sadaqah: Voluntary charity in Islam.

  • Umm al-Mu’mineen: “Mother of the Believers” (a title for the Prophet’s wives).
Reflective Questions:
• How did Khadijah’s (RA) generosity help Islam grow?

  • What can you share with others (toys, time, kindness) to follow her example?

Drag-and-drop scenarios to decide how to help others (e.g., “A hungry neighbor” → “Share your lunch”).
